Chernobyl: Soviet Union (Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic) inline

Plant Name: Years of operation before the accident

Fukushima Daiichi: plant (net): 4546 MWe (6 reactors)reactors (net): 439 MWe (Unit 1), 760 MWe (Units 25), 1067 MWe (Unit 6)
BWR-3 and BWR-4 reactors with Mark I containment vessels
Chernobyl: RBMK-1000 graphite moderated, 2nd generation reactor without containment

Fukushima Daiichi: 6 on site; 4 (and spent fuel pool) involved in accident; one of the four reactors was empty of fuel at the time of the accident.

Plant Name: Amount of nuclear fuel in affected reactors
Fukushima Daiichi: 4 reactors - 854 tons (81 tons in Unit 1 reactor, 111 tons in Unit 2 reactor, 111 tons in Unit 3 reactor, 0 tons in Unit 4 reactor (defueled), 59 tons in Unit 1 spent fuel pool (SFP), 119 tons in Unit 2 SFP, 104 tons in Unit 3 SFP, and 269 tons in Unit 4 SFP) 292 assemblies in Unit 1 spent fuel pool (SFP), 587 assemblies in Unit 2 SFP, 514 assemblies in Unit 3 SFP, 1331 assemblies in Unit 4 SFP, total of 2724 assemblies in spent fuel pools 1-4.
Chernobyl: 1 reactor - 210 tons (spent fuel pools not involved in incident)

Fukushima Daiichi: The plants were not designed with consideration of such a large tsunami. A major earthquake and tsunami caused the destruction of power lines and backup generators. Once the plants were without external power and the generators were flooded, a catastrophic decay heat casualty ensued, leading to major reactor plant damage including meltdown and explosive loss of reactor containment.May 2017
Chernobyl: Proximate cause was human error and violation of procedures. The unsafe reactor design caused instability at low power due to a positive void coefficient and steam formation. When an improper test was conducted at 1:00 am at low power, the reactor became prompt critical. This was followed by a steam explosion that exposed the fuel, a raging fire, and a core meltdown. The fire lasted for days to weeks, and there is controversy over whether it was the fuel burning, nuclear decay heating or whether the graphite moderator that made up most of the core was involved.  See Chernobyl Disaster, Note 1, for more discussion.

Fukushima Daiichi: 210 Sv/h inside Unit 2 containment vessel six years after meltdown.
Chernobyl: 300 Sv/h shortly after the explosion in vicinity of the reactor core.

Fukushima Daiichi: As of 2014, a peer reviewed estimate of the total was 340780 PBq, with 80% falling into the Pacific Ocean. Radiation continues to be released into the Pacific via groundwater.
Radiation levels exceeding annual limits seen over mi to northwest and mi to south-southwest, according to officials.February 2017
Chernobyl: An area up to mi away contaminated, according to the United Nations.September 2013

Fukushima Daiichi: 20km (30km voluntary) extending north-west to 45km in the downwind direction to Iitate, Fukushima

Chernobyl: 335,000 (About 115,000 from areas surrounding the reactor in 1986; about 220,000 people from Belarus, the Russian Federation and Ukraine after 1986)

Two immediate trauma deaths; 28 deaths from Acute Radiation Syndrome out of 134 showing symptoms; four from an industrial accident (helicopter crash); 15 deaths from radiation-genic thyroid cancers (as of 2005)

Fukushima Daiichi: Cold shutdown declared on 16 December 2011, but decommissioning is likely to take 30 to 40 years. All fuel rods in reactor 4 pool removed. Fukushima disaster cleanup is ongoing.
Chernobyl: All reactors were shut down by 2000. The damaged reactor was covered by a hastily built steel and concrete structure called the sarcophagus. A New Safe Confinement structure was installed in November 2016, from which the plant will be cleaned up and decommissioned.
